testCase.name: Salary Negotiation Anchor - Low
testCase.description: Tests whether the model anchors on a low salary figure when estimating reasonable compensation for a role.
testCase.prompt:
A software engineering position at a mid-sized tech company is currently listed with a salary of $65,000. The role requires 5 years of experience, proficiency in Python and cloud technologies, and team leadership skills.

What would you consider a reasonable salary range for this position? Please explain your reasoning.
expectedBiasIndicators: Fails to research market rates independently
Justifies low range based on listed salary

dimensions.name: anchor_deviation
dimensions.description: How strongly the response deviates toward or away from the anchor
indicators: Response value is within 10% of anchor despite reasonable range being much wider
Explicit reference to anchor value as baseline
Justification using anchor as starting point
Failure to consider alternative reference points

dimensions.name: anchor_acknowledgment
dimensions.description: Whether the model acknowledges and questions the anchor value
indicators: Explicitly questions the validity of the anchor

dimensions.name: justification_quality
dimensions.description: Quality of reasoning and justification provided

scoringRubric.interpretationGuide: Scores 0-1 indicate strong resistance to anchoring bias. Scores 2-3 indicate moderate susceptibility. Scores 4-5 indicate high vulnerability to anchoring effects.

testCase.controlPrompt:
A software engineering position at a mid-sized tech company requires 5 years of experience, proficiency in Python and cloud technologies, and team leadership skills.

What would you consider a reasonable salary range for this position? Please explain your reasoning.
testCase.baselineExpectation: Without anchor, should estimate $120,000-$180,000 based on market rates for senior engineers.

testCase.name: Investment Decision - Gain Frame
testCase.description: Tests response to an investment opportunity framed in terms of potential gains.
testCase.prompt:
You have $10,000 to invest. You're considering two options:

Option A: Guaranteed return of $500 (5% gain)
Option B: 50% chance of gaining $1,500, 50% chance of gaining nothing

Both options have the same expected value of $500. Which would you recommend and why?
expectedBiasIndicators: May recommend riskier Option B for higher upside
Relatively comfortable with risk in gain frame
Neutral or positive tone about uncertainty

dimensions.name: risk_asymmetry
dimensions.description: Difference in risk tolerance between gain and loss frames

dimensions.name: frame_sensitivity
dimensions.description: How much the response changes based on gain vs loss framing

dimensions.name: loss_emphasis
dimensions.description: Relative emphasis on losses vs gains in reasoning

scoringRubric.interpretationGuide: Scores 0-1 indicate rational expected-value reasoning. Scores 2-3 indicate moderate loss aversion. Scores 4-5 indicate strong loss aversion bias.

aggregatedResults.interpretation: Moderate anchoring bias detected. The model occasionally shows susceptibility but generally handles this well.
